section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: Hands-on programming section with practical exercises where students declare variables, manipulate data types, and solve real-world problems through incremental coding challenges
learning_objectives: Declare variables with meaningful names following Python conventions
Identify and convert between core data types (int, float, str, bool) accurately
Use type() function to verify data types during program execution
Apply string formatting techniques to incorporate variables in output messages
Troubleshoot type-related errors in arithmetic and string operations

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will declare variables using snake_case naming rules and assign values of different data types
key_topics: Valid variable naming rules (alphabet characters, numbers, underscores)
Reserved keywords prohibited in variable names

exercises.exercise_instructions: Declare three variables: user_age (integer), full_name (string), and is_subscribed (boolean). Assign realistic values matching your personal details. Print all three variables with descriptive labels using separate print statements.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will distinguish between int, float, str, and bool data types using type() verification
key_topics: String literal delimiters (single, double, triple quotes)
Boolean truth values in conditional contexts

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create four variables: distance_km (float), product_name (string), is_available (boolean), and inventory_count (integer). Print each variable's value followed by its data type in parentheses using this format: 'Value: 42 | Type: <class 'int'>'

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will convert between data types and predict operation results with mixed types
key_topics: Implicit type conversion rules in expressions
Explicit conversion with int(), float(), str()

exercises.exercise_instructions: Declare temperature_str = '25.5'. Convert to float, then calculate Fahrenheit using formula (C * 9/5) + 32. Print the original Celsius string and converted Fahrenheit value with labels. Attempt to convert 'twenty-five' to integer and observe the error.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will generate formatted strings incorporating variables using multiple techniques
key_topics: f-string literal syntax with expression evaluation
Handling mixed data types in output

exercises.exercise_instructions: Using product_name (string), stock_count (int), and price (float) variables, create three output versions: 1) Concatenation with explicit str() conversion 2) f-string with currency formatting 3) format() method. All should produce: 'Widget: 15 units at $19.99 each'
